div1.p: Kean discusses Lazear's discovery of intrinsic and extrinsic incubation in mosquitoes.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, [August 3, 1946]
div1.opener:
AC
K
2804 N STREET, N. W.
WASHINGTON 7, D. C.
Aug 3, 1946
My dear Colonel Hench
div1.p:
From my delay in answering your
fine letter of the 16th July you would
never guess the pleasure that it gave
me. I was quite thrilled at the pleasure
that it gave you to meet Houston Lazear
and to explain to him that his father was
a man of fine accomplishments and
great courage and strength of character,
who shared more than any one else in
the credit of Walter Reed for clearing up
the mysteries of intrinsic and extrinsic
incubation of the yellow fever infection
in the mosquito, which had defeated
the experiments of Finlay's experi-
ments on volunteers. Thus he had
2
become a great and famous man whose
merits were recognized by everyone who
ever heard of them except by his own
crazy wife. And I am so pleased that
this pleasure should come to you whose
interest in this great Episode began with
your study of his father's career at the
request of your common Alma mater.
Also as I know, but you could not
tell him, that you are the best qualified
man in the whole world to tell him
the story which had been held back
from him by his mother. No wonder
that Houston Lazear and his wife hung
on your words and wanted to see as
much of you and of Mrs Hench as
they could. I am so pleased to hear
also of your visits with the Trubys and
that Mrs Hench should get to know
Mrs Truby.
3
Is'nt Mrs. Truby a perfect dear.
It is good too to have your good report
of Gen. Truby's present condition. He
has written to me recently of his physi-
cal condition but I am glad to have
a confirmation from your keen eyes.
Your friend Dr. Crain has been very kind
to us and to old Elizabeth. She went
to see him on July 18 and was treated
with great care and consideration. He
examined her heart and her knees and
prescribed for her and told her to come
back at a certain date. But she went
home and went to bed and has not
been back to see him or to work for us
since. She came to see us a week ago
and stayed a couple of hours to talk over
her affairs with Cornelia and me but
she says she is too sick to work and
I am afraid that she is, or thinks that
4
she is which amounts to the same thing.
She has a curious phobia which is that
she cannot use an elevator without being
affected with fainting or vertigo and so
nothing will induce her to use an elevator.
As Dr Crain's office is on the 7th floor of
the building, she, with her weak heart and
rheumatic knees and weak ankles and
over weight, would not use the elevator but
climbed the 7 flights of stairs! No wonder
she went home and went to bed!
I wrote to Dr. Crain to explain why she
had not come for her second examination
and got a second letter from him today
I had hoped to talk her out of her phobia and
Cornelia offered to go with her and go
up in the elevator with her. But Dr. Crain
says there is very little chance of doing any
thing in such cases at her age. He offers
if I will get the X rays of her knees taken
to come by and see her here. Isnt that kind
AC
K
5
Aug 3, 1946
of him. He must be a very fine man
from his letters. Old Elizabeth says that
his secretary was very kind to her. That
must have been the secretary who came
from you. We have not had any help since
Elizabeth got sick and Cornelia is quite
played out with being maid of all
work. The painters have complicated
things be being here for ten days and
have departed having the old house
with its face lifted but every thing in
in a mess, and the sashes and screens
all stuck tight. I told the head painter
that we were the most stuck-up people
in Georgetown.

I know that when you returned to Rochester
that you had a mountain of mail and
6
many demands on your time and I am
much flattered that you should push
all these things aside to write that nice
letter to me.

You have now two titles, both honorable,
and I do not know which you would
prefer to be addressed by. You see I have
addressed you in this letter by your
Army title and on the envelope by the
title that they are accustomed to know you
by in Rochester. Give me a hint when
you write. Mrs Kean joins me in cordi-
al regards to Mrs Hench
